unnormalised: Someone asked me what units of measurement are used in medicine, so I thought I'd share some common examples. It's a pretty diverse field! For liquid medications, things are often measured in mL (milliliters). For example, your cough syrup might say "take 5 mL every 4 hours." Sometimes you'll see cc's too, which is the same as mL. Injections are frequently measured in mL as well.
normalised: Someone asked me what units of measurement are used in medicine, so I thought I'd share some common examples. It's a pretty diverse field! For liquid medications, things are often measured in milliliter. For example, your cough syrup might say "take five milliliter every four hours." Sometimes you'll see c c's too, which is the same as milliliter. Injections are frequently measured in milliliter as well.

unnormalised: For solid medications, you'll typically find things in mg (milligrams) or g (grams). A common painkiller like Paracetamol comes in 500 mg tablets. Certain vitamins might be measured in mcg (micrograms), which is even smaller than a milligram – 1000 mcg equals 1 mg. And sometimes you'll see things measured in units, especially for insulin (e.g., 10 units of insulin).
normalised: For solid medications, you'll typically find things in milligram or gram. A common painkiller like Paracetamol comes in five hundred milligram tablets. Certain vitamins might be measured in microgram, which is even smaller than a milligram – one thousand microgram equals one milligram. And sometimes you'll see things measured in units, especially for insulin (e.g., ten units of insulin).

unnormalised: When talking about blood pressure, we usually use mmHg (millimeters of mercury). Normal blood pressure is around 120/80 mmHg. Body temperature is often reported in degrees Celsius (°C) or Fahrenheit (°F) - in India, °C is commonly used. A normal body temp is around 37°C. And when checking oxygen saturation, you'll see a percentage (%). A healthy SpO2 level should be above 95%.
normalised: When talking about blood pressure, we usually use millimeters of mercury. Normal blood pressure is around one hundred and twenty slash eighty millimeters of mercury. Body temperature is often reported in degree Celsius or Fahrenheit - in India, degree Celsius is commonly used. A normal body temperature is around thirty seven degree Celsius. And when checking oxygen saturation, you'll see a percentage. A healthy S p O two level should be above ninety five percent.

unnormalised: Finally, think about height and weight. Heights of patients are usually recorded in cm (centimeters) or ft & inches. Someone might be 175 cm tall or 5 ft 9 inches. Weight is typically measured in kg (kilograms). A baby might be weighed in grams (g) initially. There are lots of different units, and it really depends on what's being measured!
